{"uri": "2024-07-426747955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "06:19:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T06:19:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T06:08:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/melania-trump-rare-appearance-watch-donald-convention-speech-3178857", "title": "Melania Trump makes rare appearance to watch Donald deliver convention speech", "body": "The former first lady's presence marked the first time she has appeared in public since Trump survived an assassination attempt\n\nMelania Trump made a rare public appearance during the final night of the Republican National Convention in support of her husband Donald Trump's third bid for president.\n\nThe former first lady's presence marked the first time she has appeared in public since Trump survived an assassination attempt.\n\nMs Trump has largely steered clear of the campaign trail this year, a contrast with Trump's 2016 and 2020 campaigns when she played a larger role.\n\nIn a break from tradition, she did not deliver a speech at the landmark presidential campaign event.\n\nCampaigns often use spouses and families to humanise a candidate, with first ladies and candidates' spouses having delivered addresses at party conventions dating back to Barbara Bush's speech in 1922.\n\nMs Trump's appearance is expected to help the Republican Party show widespread unity, a theme that emerged prominently after the attempt on Trump's life last weekend.\n\nA day after the attack, she issued a statement calling on Americans to \"ascend above hate, the vitriol, and the simple-minded ideas that ignite violence\".\n\nTrump's family, minus his wife, entered the arena after he signed paperwork formally accepting the GOP nomination. They went to the family box and stood throughout lengthy speech.\n\nMs Trump entered later, smiling and waving to the crowd as she walked alone into the arena and up a flight of stairs to take her seat next to vice presidential nominee JD Vance.\n\n\"On this journey, I am deeply honoured to be joined by my amazing wife, Melania,\" Trump said to extended applause. \"And Melania, thank you very much.\"\n\nHe said she \"did something really beautiful\" when she wrote her statement pleading for unity after the shooting.\n\nLater she joined Trump on stage, startling him as she walked up behind him after his 93-minute speech, then whispered in his ear.\n\nThe rest of the Trump family joined and balloons fell from the ceiling, an iconic tradition of political conventions.\n\nAs the family lingered on stage for 20 minutes, Ms Trump stood by Trump's side being quietly affectionate, touching her husband's arm at times and sometimes chatting with Vance and his wife, Usha Vance.\n\nMs Trump has been absent from key moments of her husband's current campaign, including rallies and primary-night victory parties. She did not join him in court as he faced trial over hush money payments to porn star Stormy Daniels or for his remarks responding to the guilty verdict.\n\nIvanka Trump, the former president's eldest daughter, who also played a more visible part in the 2016 and 2020 campaigns but has not been a major feature of this current one, was also present. She did not make a speech either.\n\nAlong with her husband she held a senior role on Trump's White House staff but did not attend his 2022 announcement that he planned another presidential campaign.\n\n\"While I will always love and support my father, going forward I will do so outside the political arena,\" Ivanka Trump said in a statement at the time.", "source": {"uri": She did not attend any day of her husband's criminal trial in New York. She rarely makes a public statement about Trump - although she did after the recent assassination attempt.\n\nMelania's decision to forego an RNC speech is not surprising, but it is unclear what her exact reasoning was behind this.\n\nIn 2016, Melania faced intense scrutiny when reporters realized her speech was heavily inspired, if not directly taken, from Michelle Obama's 2016 Democratic National Convention speech. Her stately introduction stood in stark contrast with the previous speaker, the professional wrestler Hulk Hogan, who ripped his shirt off in a particularly bombastic display.\n\nMelania was then followed up by a lively Kid Rock performance afterwards.\n\nShe had earlier been pictured backstage alongside Trump by The New York Times as the former president met her upon arrival.\n\nMelania moved towards the VIP box solo, where she was sandwiched between vice presidential pick J.D. Vance and Trump's second son, Eric.\n\nThe former first lady spoke in both 2020 and 2016. She was accused of borrowing from Michelle Obama's 2008 speech in her first appearance in 2016.\n\nOn CNN, Kaitlan Collins, citing sources, said \"they tried really hard to get her to give a speech tonight,\" adding that \"several people personally appealed to her and she had no interest in doing so.\"\n\nMelania sat stoically in the VIP box and did not appear to mingle with the family gathered at the event. She appeared to be a mix of seriousness and smiles as she waited for husband Donald to take the stage. Barron Trump was not in attendance.\n\nAs Kid Rock raged on, Melania remained seated, despite the rest of the family giving him a standing ovation.\n\nMelania has been notably absent from the 2024 campaign trail, making only a few private appearances. She released a statement after the attempted assassination attempt of Trump last weekend, decrying political violence while giving fans some insight into her very personal life.\n\n\"When I watched that violent bullet strike my husband, Donald, I realized my life, and Barron's life, were on the brink of a devastating change. {"uri": "8232617298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "00:26:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T00:26:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T00:25:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/trump-family-reshapes-republican-party-in-its-own-image/article_59ecfe1a-6bc0-51fd-a5c5-3ecba61d25d5.html", "title": "Trump family reshapes Republican Party in its own image", "body": "For Donald Trump, the campaign to return to the White House is a family affair.\n\nHis sons Donald Jr. and Eric have been ubiquitous at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, flanking their father at almost all his public appearances.\n\nDuring Trump's first term in office between 2017 and 2021, they helped him make key decisions, and they now work to ensure the party leadership is comprised of loyal allies.\n\nMost recently, their input helped tip Trump towards picking Ohio Senator J.D. Vance as his running mate, a new addition to the inner circle.\n\n\"He couldn't choose one of his sons or daughters or daughter-in-law, that just wouldn't work, of course,\" Natasha Lindstaedt, a political scientist at the University of Essex, told AFP.\n\n\"J.D. Vance and Don Jr. are very close. So he chose someone that maybe reminds him of his son or is close to his son,\" she said.\n\nA notable absence on the campaign trail this year, however, has been former first lady Melania Trump, who has been all but invisible throughout Trump's rallies and protracted court appearances.\n\n- Where is Melania? -\n\nIn a marked break from precedent, Melania has been largely absent in recent months from her husband's political life, with the notable exception of a fiery statement after an attempted assassination attempt on him on Saturday.\n\nPrior to that, however, she had spoken sparingly and not accompanied her husband during court appearances in a case that saw him convicted of covering up hush money payments made to porn star Stormy Daniels, who alleged she had a sexual encounter with the real estate tycoon.\n\n\"She's a complete enigma,\" Lindstaedt said, adding that the former model did not \"play the typical role\" of a former first lady.\n\n\"Although she seemed to share similar views to Trump on a lot of issues, not on all, but on a lot of issues, she has a very conservative world view, she doesn't seem to care that much what people think and kind of does her own thing.\"\n\n- Three generations -\n\nThe rest of Trump's family has offered the former president a way to soften his image in the aftermath of the recent convictions and other legal woes.\n\nHis eldest granddaughter, 17-year-old Kai Trump, spoke at the RNC Wednesday night to describe the \"very caring and loving\" patriarch.\n\n\"He's just a normal grandpa, he gives us candy and soda when our parents aren't looking,\" she said.\n\nThe teenage daughter of Donald Jr. spoke of their shared love of golf, even when the former president tries to psych her out when playing against her.\n\nMore from this section Copenhagen Offers Prizes to Eco-Friendly Tourists - TaiwanPlus News Must See! Japanese Engineers Create Living Skin Robo-Face That Can Smile at You Meet the candidates for U.S. House of Representatives, Congressional District 10\n\n\"I don't let him get to me, but I have to remind him I'm a Trump, too,\" she said.\n\n- Nepotism -\n\nLike wagons hitched to their father's train, Donald Jr., Eric and Ivanka have been pulled along to success, along with their friends and families.\n\nLindstaedt pointed to two examples of Trump spouses achieving power: Eric Trump's wife Lara Trump, who was recently appointed co-chair of the Republican National Committee, and Ivanka's husband Jared Kushner, who Trump appointed as an advisor and entrusted with figuring out peace in the Middle East.\n\n\"Suddenly people who have no expertise, no training, no ethics training, maybe they're not even going properly through security clearances, are given access to the most powerful positions,\" Lindstaedt said.\n\n\"And we see when this happens in non-democracies and the dictatorships, how it usually goes very badly.\"\n\nNatalie Koch, who researches geopolitics and authoritarianism at Syracuse University, said Trump's nepotism is nothing new.\n\n\"The Trump organization is a family business, but once he took office the first time, and then you could really see that he brought that into the political realm and into the White House,\" Koch told AFP.\n\n- Children's roles -\n\nEach of Trump's children has been entrusted with different duties during this campaign.\n\nDon Jr., the eldest at age 46, is a big proponent of his father's far-right \"Make America Great Again\" (MAGA) ideology.\n\nSpeaking at the Republican National Convention, he extolled the image of his father raising his fist after the assassination attempt last weekend.\n\nIvanka, 42, had played a role in Trump's administration but has since devoted herself to personal matters.\n\nEric, 40, has doubled down on Trump's claims that the 2020 election was rigged. At the convention, he appeared with delegates from Florida and claimed -- without evidence -- that the Democratic Party was planning to win this year's election fraudulently.\n\nTrump's fourth child, Tiffany, 30, was also in attendance at the Republican National Convention.\n\nHis youngest child, 18-year-old Barron, whom he had with current wife Melania, appears to take after his mother's preference for the background, declining to be a delegate from Florida at the convention this year.\n\nmav/llu/jgc/aha/acb", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "moises_avila@reformer.com", "name": "Mois\u00e9s \u00c1vila", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_Jr.", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump Jr."}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Eric Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melania_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Melania Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._D._Vance", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "J. Credit: Marc Nozell from Merrimack, New Hampshire, USA, CC BY 2.0 , via Wikimedia Commons\n\nMelania Trump made a seldom-seen public appearance on Thursday night at the Republican National Convention, seemingly demonstrating her support for her husband Donald Trump. However, she deviated from the customary practice of delivering a speech at the event.\n\nMelania emerged from the backstage area and proceeded to go onto the convention floor while the choral symphony composed by Ludwig Van Beethoven, Symphony No. 9 in D Minor, Op. 125 was being played through the loudspeakers. Her dignified presentation was noticeably different from that of the preceding speaker, the professional wrestler Hulk Hogan, who tore off his shirt in a particularly flamboyant manner.\n\nSubsequently, a spirited Kid Rock performance followed Melania's appearance.The New York Times had already captured an image of her backstage with Trump as he greeted her upon her arrival.\n\nMelania Trump proceeded towards the VIP box alone, where she found herself positioned between vice presidential nominee J.D. Vance and Eric, Trump's second son. The ex-president's wife delivered speeches in 2020 and 2016. On her initial public appearance in 2016, she faced allegations of plagiarizing Michelle Obama's 2008 speech.\n\nAccording to sources reported by Kaitlan Collins on CNN, concerted efforts were made to persuade her to deliver a speech tonight. Despite repeated personal appeals, she expressed no inclination to do so.\n\nMelania remained composed in the VIP box and did not seem to socialize with the assembled family members at the occasion. She exuded a combination of gravitas and joy as she patiently awaited her husband, Donald's appearance on stage. Barron Trump was absent.\n\nWhile Kid Rock performed energetically, Melania remained seated, unlike the rest of the family, who enthusiastically stood up to applaud him.\n\nMelania's presence on the 2024 campaign trail has been conspicuously limited, with only a few discreet appearances. Spouses of presidential hopefuls traditionally address the RNC crowd; Melania herself took the stage in both the 2016 and 2020 conventions, where her speeches bore striking resemblances to those of former first lady Michelle Obama.\n\nThis appearance follows shortly after Melania's public statement regarding the assassination attempt on Donald Trump last Saturday at a campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania. \"When I watched that violent bullet strike my husband, Donald, I realised my life, and Barron's life, were on the brink of devastating change,\" she said in her statement.\n\nREAD MORE: Trump watches Hulk Hogan rip off his shirt in fiery RNC speech as he dubs ex-President 'heroic'\n\nThe final day of the conference has seen a wide variety of speakers, from the general manager of Trump's golf resorts to former pro wrestler Hulk Hogan, who shredded his shirt in front of attendees as he shared his passion for \"Trumpmania.\"\n\nFormer first lady Melania Trump was cheered loudly when mentioned by other speakers during the previous nights, but she finally entered the arena on the final night wearing a red jacket and pencil skirt suit and waving to the crowds.\n\nMelania has been conspicuously absent from the ex-president's campaign trail, reports the Mirror US.\n\nThe former First Lady appeared dressed all in red as she walked into the Milwaukee convention hall, shortly before her husband took to the stage. The speech marks his first public comments since a 20-year-old with a rifle tried to shoot him at a Pennsylvania rally on Saturday.\n\nShe will not be speaking at the convention. Her office was the one that declined an invitation for Barron Trump to appear as a Florida delegate after the state's Republican party chose him to join the delegation saying the couple's youngest son had \"prior commitments.\"\n\nHer presence helps the Republican party show unity, a theme that has emerged more prominently after the attempt on Trump's life. In all, over a dozen family members attended Thursday night when the Republican nominee gave his speech, including several of his 10 grandchildren.\n\nTrump formally accepted the Republican nomination for president for a third time Thursday and thanked Americans for their support after he was injured and a man died in an assassination attempt at the former president's campaign rally last week. He also thanked his family, several of whom had made speeches recalling Saturday's assassination attempt.\n\nFact-checking RNC Day 4: What Trump, other speakers get right and wrong\n\nFormer First Lady Melania Trump, who has largely avoided public appearances during the 2024 campaign, made her entrance Thursday night and sat next to vice-presidential pick JD Vance. Trump's daughter Ivanka Trump and her husband, Jared Kushner, also made their debut, joining a parade of relatives to take their seats in the family box ahead of the keynote speeches Thursday. The pair were followed by Tiffany Trump and her husband, Michael Boulos, and by the two eldest Trump sons.\n\nMore: Donald Trump and his family through the years in photos\n\nDonald Trump Jr., who has long been a spokesperson for his father, was one of four Trumps to give speeches at the convention. He gave his address Wednesday, just before Usha Vance and JD Vance took to the stage. Don Jr. is the executive vice president of the Trump Organization, the holding company for all of Donald Trump's business ventures and investments.\n\nDonald Trump's oldest granddaughter, Kai Trump, became the first of his grandchildren to give a campaign address when she joined her father, Don Jr., on stage Wednesday. Kimberly Guilfoyle, Don Jr.'s fianc\u00e9e, also spoke Wednesday.\n\nTrump's second-oldest son, Eric Trump, spoke the following night, while his wife, Co-Chair of the Republican National Committee Lara Trump, gave her speech Tuesday night.\n\nThe youngest of Trump's children, Barron Trump, was not present, which Trump jokingly acknowledged in his speech when he thanked his family members by name during his speech Thursday night.\n\nKathryn Palmer is an elections fellow for USA TODAY. The post from Haberman provoked a denial from Trump, who apologized to his wife for the \"Fake News and fictional stories\" reported by \"the Fake News Media.\"\n\nEric Trump and Donald Trump Jr., the former president's eldest sons, have remained public defenders of their father, attacking the four indictments and supporting his presidential campaign efforts. Trump's daughter Ivanka and son-in-law Jared Kushner, the two most prominent family members in his administration, have backed away from his campaign this time, with Ivanka Trump saying she would be prioritizing her children and family over further time in the political arena. {"uri": "8232717647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "02:40:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T02:40:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T02:37:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://conservativeangle.com/who-kai-trump-and-other-members-of-trumps-family/", "title": "Who Kai Trump and other members of Trump's family? - Conservative Angle", "body": "(NewsNation) -- Several members of former President Donald Trump's family will be at the Republican National Convention as he accepts the GOP nomination for the 2024 general election Thursday.\n\nMany of Trump's children and in-laws have played a big role in his campaign and in his business ventures.\n\nHere's a breakdown of who they are.\n\nMelania Trump is Donald Trump's wife and mother of his youngest child, Barron.\n\nBorn on April 26, 1970, in Novo Mesto, Slovenia, she is the only first lady to become a naturalized U.S. citizen.\n\nHer campaign as first lady, \"Be Best,\" aimed to promote \"a world for children based on healthy living, kindness, and respect,\" according to the White House. It quickly drew criticism, however, with CNN noting that it didn't have specific policy or legislation goals and that much of what it accomplished came through partnerships that already existed in the federal government.\n\nMelania Trump won't give a speech Thursday, though she will be accompanying the president at the Republican National Convention.\n\nNewsNation's Robert Sherman reports that Melania Trump has missed several key moments of her husband's campaign, including the announcement that he is running in 2024 and the first presidential debate.\n\nBarron Trump graduated high school in 2024. His childhood consisted of attending \"prestigious\" private schools on Manhattan's Upper West Side, People magazine wrote.\n\nWhen his dad was elected president, Barron Trump and Melania stayed in Manhattan so he could finish the school year, then moved to Maryland and into the White House that summer. He graduated high school in May.\n\nPeople writes that even though he's Donald Trump's son, Barron Trump has largely stayed out of the spotlight.\n\nDonald Trump Jr. is the former president's eldest son and an executive vice president of the Trump Organization.\n\nThe Trump Organization website states that Donald Trump Jr. \"works to expand the company's real estate, retail, commercial, hotel and golf interests\" as an executive of their Florida-based business.\n\n\"He is involved in all aspects of the company's development, from deal evaluation, analysis and pre-development planning to construction, branding, marketing, operations, sales and leasing,\" the website said.\n\nAt the Republican National Convention, Donald Trump Jr. made a speech praising his father for his actions after the assassination attempt at a rally on Saturday in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"It's a choice between one team that wants to build this country up and another that wants to tear this country down,\" Donald Trump Jr. said.\n\nLike his older brother, Eric Trump is an executive vice president at his father's company, overseeing its management and operations, including new project acquisition, development and construction, per the Trump Organization.\n\nSpeaking to NewsNation's Chris Cuomo on Wednesday night, Eric Trump said the attempted assassination of his father changed his father's message and that he \"probably realized what's important in life.\"\n\n\"He realized he could have been dead,\" Eric Trump said. \"Had he not moved his face one inch ... you would have had a former president, very likely future president, get executed on TV.\"\n\nThe fianc\u00e9e of Donald Trump Jr., Kimberly Guilfoyle, is an American TV personality and prosecutor who received a law degree from the University of San Francisco in 1994, the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel said.\n\nBefore entering a relationship with Donald Trump Jr., Guilfoyle was married to Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom, making her a first lady from 2003 to 2005 when Newsom was mayor of San Francisco.\n\nWhile the Journal Sentinel writes that she's probably best known for being on the Court TV show \"Both Sides\" and Fox News' \"The Five,\" she's made other television appearances as well and even has her own eponymous show.\n\nOn Tuesday, Guilfoyle spoke at the RNC to say November will be \"the most important election in our lifetime,\" according to USA Today.\n\nOldest daughter Ivanka Trump was an adviser to her father when he was president but has since said she does \"not plan to be involved in politics\" because she wants to prioritize her children and \"the private life we are creating as a family.\"\n\nShe previously served as an executive at the Trump Organization and appeared on Donald Trump's reality TV show, \"The Apprentice.\"\n\nAs part of New York Attorney General Letitia James' investigation into the Trump Organization, Ivanka Trump testified about the company's business practices.\n\nJared Kushner is married to Ivanka Trump and was in her father's closest circle of White House aides, Business Insider writes.\n\nThe publication pointed out that while Kushner's family has a background in Democratic politics, like the former Republican president, they made their money in real estate. A former owner of the \"New York Observer,\" Kushner took over the family's real estate company when his father, Charles, was convicted in 2005 of filing false tax returns, retaliating against a cooperating witness and making false statements to the Federal Election Commission.\n\nDonald Trump later pardoned Charles Kushner in 2020.\n\nAfter serving in Trump's administration, Kushner founded the investment firm Affinity Partners.\n\nDonald Trump's youngest daughter and only child with ex-wife Marla Maples, Tiffany Trump, went to the University of Pennsylvania before getting a law degree from Georgetown.\n\nTiffany Trump married Michael Boulous two years ago.\n\nTiffany Trump's mother, Marla Maples, is Donald Trump's ex-wife. The two met in 1984, and the year after, Maples moved to New York to be a model and actor.\n\nMaples told The Evening Standard in a recent interview that she has never been a fan of politics but found herself \"in the throes of it\" when her ex-husband ran for president.\n\n\"My role was to give Tiffany strength,\" Maples, now a \"spirituality and wellness advocate\" running marlamaples.com, said.\n\nNow, though, The Evening Standard reports that Maples wants to \"join the frontline.\"\n\n\"I'm ready. I am available if needed, and I'm not sitting back anymore,\" she said. \"I want to step out more, share more and not be afraid of positive or negative outcomes that come from speaking out.\"\n\nLara Trump is the Republican National Convention's co-chair. She's been married to Eric Trump since November 8, 2014, with whom she has two children.\n\nIn her earlier years, she worked for Inside Edition and was a contributor to Fox News.\n\nMost recently, Lara Trump spoke at the RNC on Tuesday. While she initially had a \"very different\" speech planned, Lara Trump said to CBS News that she rewrote it in light of the assassination attempt on the former president.\n\nIn her interview with the news outlet, Lara Trump said her focus is \"on this election right now to get my father-in-law reelected.\"\n\n\"And then you never know,\" she added. \"Never say never with Trump.\"\n\nKai Trump, Donald Trump's eldest grandchild, made her first foray into the political arena when she made a speech at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday.\n\n\"I'm speaking today to share the side of my grandpa that people don't often see. To me, he's just a normal grandpa,\" Kai Trump said, according to NewsNation partner The Hill. \"He gives us candy and soda when our parents aren't looking. He always wants to know how we're doing in school.\"\n\nHer social media shows her to be an avid golfer, along with Donald Trump, with whom she posted a picture after winning a tournament on one of his Florida golf courses.\n\nVanessa Trump is Donald Jr.'s ex-wife and mother of Kai as well as four other children.\n\nShe's a former model, working both on the runway and in commercials.", "source": Usha Vance was also pictured stood with Melania, alongside the president's daughter Ivanka, and son Eric.\n\nThe former first lady was not mentioned on the list of speakers at the RNC for Thursday.\n\nSpeculation about Melania's whereabouts have swirled for days, and she has yet to be pictured at the convention which has been running since Monday. Other members of the Trump family have been pictured on the convention floor, and in the box with their father.\n\nHer appearance in Milwaukee marks her first major political appearance with Trump since he announced his 2024 campaign almost two years ago. Sources told Politico that the former first lady, who is a deeply private person, was deeply shaken by the shocking assassination attempt.\n\nShortly following the incident on Saturday during a campaign rally in Butler Pennsylvania, Melania released a statement in which she described would-be-assassin as a \"monster.\"\n\n\"When I watched that violent bullet strike my husband, Donald, I realized my life, and Barron's life, were on the brink of devastating change. I am grateful to the brave secret service agents and law enforcement officials who risked their own lives to protect my husband,\" she wrote.\n\n\"To the families of the innocent victims who are now suffering from this heinous act, I humbly offer my sincerest sympathy. Your need to summon your inner strength for such a terrible reason saddens me.\n\n\"A monster who recognized my husband as an inhuman political machine attempted to ring out Donald's passion - his laughter, ingenuity, love of music, and inspiration. {"uri": "2024-07-426564773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "01:05:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T01:05:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T23:44:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/trump-family-reshapes-republican-party-in-its-own-image/article_f1f9f26d-ef5f-5cff-b247-4892711f5f4f.html", "title": "Trump family reshapes Republican Party in its own image", "body": "For Donald Trump, the campaign to return to the White House is a family affair.\n\nHis sons Donald Jr. and Eric have been ubiquitous at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, flanking their father at almost all his public appearances.\n\nDuring Trump's first term in office between 2017 and 2021, they helped him make key decisions, and they now work to ensure the party leadership is comprised of loyal allies.\n\nMost recently, their input helped tip Trump towards picking Ohio Senator J.D. Vance as his running mate, a new addition to the inner circle.\n\n\"He couldn't choose one of his sons or daughters or daughter-in-law, that just wouldn't work, of course,\" Natasha Lindstaedt, a political scientist at the University of Essex, told AFP.\n\n\"J.D. Vance and Don Jr. are very close. So he chose someone that maybe reminds him of his son or is close to his son,\" she said.\n\nA notable absence on the campaign trail this year, however, has been former first lady Melania Trump, who has been all but invisible throughout Trump's rallies and protracted court appearances.\n\n- Where is Melania? -\n\nIn a marked break from precedent, Melania has been largely absent in recent months from her husband's political life, with the notable exception of a fiery statement after an attempted assassination attempt on him on Saturday.\n\nPrior to that, however, she had spoken sparingly and not accompanied her husband during court appearances in a case that saw him convicted of covering up hush money payments made to porn star Stormy Daniels, who alleged she had a sexual encounter with the real estate tycoon.\n\n\"She's a complete enigma,\" Lindstaedt said, adding that the former model did not \"play the typical role\" of a former first lady.\n\n\"Although she seemed to share similar views to Trump on a lot of issues, not on all, but on a lot of issues, she has a very conservative world view, she doesn't seem to care that much what people think and kind of does her own thing.\"\n\n- Three generations -\n\nThe rest of Trump's family has offered the former president a way to soften his image in the aftermath of the recent convictions and other legal woes.\n\nHis eldest granddaughter, 17-year-old Kai Trump, spoke at the RNC Wednesday night to describe the \"very caring and loving\" patriarch.\n\n\"He's just a normal grandpa, he gives us candy and soda when our parents aren't looking,\" she said.\n\nThe teenage daughter of Donald Jr. spoke of their shared love of golf, even when the former president tries to psych her out when playing against her.\n\n\"I don't let him get to me, but I have to remind him I'm a Trump, too,\" she said.\n\n- Nepotism -\n\nLike wagons hitched to their father's train, Donald Jr., Eric and Ivanka have been pulled along to success, along with their friends and families.\n\nLindstaedt pointed to two examples of Trump spouses achieving power: Eric Trump's wife Lara Trump, who was recently appointed co-chair of the Republican National Committee, and Ivanka's husband Jared Kushner, who Trump appointed as an advisor and entrusted with figuring out peace in the Middle East.\n\n\"Suddenly people who have no expertise, no training, no ethics training, maybe they're not even going properly through security clearances, are given access to the most powerful positions,\" Lindstaedt said.\n\n\"And we see when this happens in non-democracies and the dictatorships, how it usually goes very badly.\"\n\nNatalie Koch, who researches geopolitics and authoritarianism at Syracuse University, said Trump's nepotism is nothing new.\n\n\"The Trump organization is a family business, but once he took office the first time, and then you could really see that he brought that into the political realm and into the White House,\" Koch told AFP.\n\n- Children's roles -\n\nEach of Trump's children has been entrusted with different duties during this campaign.\n\nDon Jr., the eldest at age 46, is a big proponent of his father's far-right \"Make America Great Again\" (MAGA) ideology.\n\nSpeaking at the Republican National Convention, he extolled the image of his father raising his fist after the assassination attempt last weekend.\n\nIvanka, 42, had played a role in Trump's administration but has since devoted herself to personal matters.\n\nEric, 40, has doubled down on Trump's claims that the 2020 election was rigged. At the convention, he appeared with delegates from Florida and claimed -- without evidence -- that the Democratic Party was planning to win this year's election fraudulently.\n\nTrump's fourth child, Tiffany, 30, was also in attendance at the Republican National Convention.\n\nHis youngest child, 18-year-old Barron, whom he had with current wife Melania, appears to take after his mother's preference for the background, declining to be a delegate from Florida at the convention this year.\n\nmav/llu/jgc/aha/acb\n\nMore from this section\n\nLenderLogix Q2 2024 Homebuyer Intelligence Report Data Shows Home Buying Activity and Fees Collected by Fee Chaser Remain Steady Thus Far in 2024\n\nHow to Unlock a Disabled iPhone without iTunes? She will not address the delegates.\n\nShe and her dad are extremely close. But Thursday's appearance is the first time she joined him for a campaign appearance in his 2024 election bid.\n\nAnd she was at her father's side after the horrific attempt on his life.\n\nThe former first daughter met Donald Trump upon his arrival in Bedminster, N.J., on Saturday night after the attempted assassination. She also spoke with him on the phone while he was in the hospital on Saturday night, sources close to the campaign told DailyMail.com.\n\nAfter the horrific attempt on her father's life, Ivanka took to social media to thank supporters and said she was 'praying for America' after the act of 'senseless violence'.\n\nShe also thanked the Secret Service for their response in taking down the gunman.\n\n'I love you Dad, today and always,' the former First Daughter wrote on X.\n\nIvanka added: 'Thank you for your love and prayers for my father and for the other victims of today's senseless violence in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n'I am grateful to the Secret Service and all the other law enforcement officers for their quick and decisive actions today. I continue to pray for our country.'\n\nShe also said she believed her mom Ivana was watching over her father.\n\n'Two years ago today, my mom passed away. I believe she was watching over Dad last night during the attempt on his life. I miss her every day and pray for the safety of the family and friends she left behind,' Ivanka noted Sunday morning on social media.\n\nBut while she has supported her father's goal to return to the White House, she is doing so from behind the scenes.\n\nIvanka's decision is in stark contrast to the 2020 election when she introduced her father at that year's convention. She was also heavily involved in the 2016 convention.\n\nBut she has done a 180 on politics since Donald Trump lost that contest.\n\nIvanka opened up about her decision to leave politics in a rare interview. In an hour-long interview with Lex Fridman, she said she wanted to spend more time with her three children and, after four years of serving in her father's White House, felt like she 'left it all on the field.'\n\n'I spent four years in Washington. I feel like I left it all on the field. I feel really good about it and I feel really privileged to have been able to do what I did,' she said.\n\nShe said, however, she is father's top supporter, as the former president battles multiple legal cases.\n\n'On a human level, it's my father and I love him very much, so it's painful to experience, but ultimately, I wish it didn't have to be this way,' she said.\n\nIvanka was a senior advisor in Trump's administration from 2017 until 2021, but she has not been heavily involved in his second bid for the White House.\n\nFormer President and 2024 Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump (L) stands with Co-chair of the Republican National Committee Lara Trump (R), (from top L) daughter Ivanka Trump, daughter Tiffany Trump and her husband Michael Boulos\n\nAs Usha Chilukuri Vance, Ivanka Trump former first lady Melania Trump and Eric Trump watch, Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump and Republican vice presidential candidate Sen. JD Vance, R-Ohio, sign paperwork to officially accept the nomination\n\nWhen Donald Trump announced his bid for re-election last year, Ivanka said in a statement posted to social media that she loved her father but would be staying out of politics. She was not at his announcement speech. Nor did she attend the first presidential debate.\n\n'I love my father very much. This time around, I'm choosing to prioritize my young children and the private life we are creating as a family,' the former White House adviser said. 'While I will always love and support my father, going forward I will do so outside the political arena,' she said at the time.\n\nShe also was one of the few family members who didn't join him at his trial in New York earlier this year, when the former president was being prosecuted over hush-money paid to porn star Stormy Daniels.\n\n'It was a decision rooted in me being a parent, really thinking about what they need from me now. Politics is a rough business and I think it's one that you also can't dabble in, I think you have to be either all in or all out.'\n\nIvanka referenced 'the cost' her children would pay from her absence were she to go all in on the campaign trail, adding 'I'm not willing to make them bear that cost.'\n\n'As their mom, I think it's really important that I do what's right for them. I think there a lot of ways you can serve, the enormity, the scale of what can be accomplished in government service, but I think there's something equally valuable in helping in your own community.'\n\nShe said there was 'a lot of darkness, a lot of negativity' in politics and says it's the opposite of 'what feels good for me as a human being.'\n\nIvanka and husband Jared Kushner have worked to distance themselves from the tumultuous world of politics amid Donald Trump's re-election campaign and his various legal woes.\n\nThey relocated to Florida with children Arabella, 12, Amid a turbulent period that saw the death of her mother and her son, Barron, leave for college, many had speculated that Melania had withdrawn her support from her husband's political endeavors.\n\nHowever, the close call in Pennsylvania appears to have prompted Melania's reemergence, as Trump pushes for a second term in the White House. Although Melania declined to speak at the RNC event, her presence was viewed as a powerful statement and an indication of a potential shift in her stance towards her husband's political aspirations.\n\nMelania's behavior stands in stark contrast to that of her counterpart, Jill Biden, who has been a constant presence by her husband's side throughout his political career. By comparison, Melania has been characterized as a \"very private person\" who has expressed a distaste for the Washington social-political scene.\n\nMelania has not commented on her decision to shield herself from the public eye. Her absence from the Daniels trial, where a series of Republican lawmakers, former administration officials, and even some of Trump's own children lent their support, was seen as a huge blow to Trump's defense. Legal experts noted that the presence of a defendant's spouse in the courtroom can often humanize the client and sway the jury.\n\nWashington Post associate editor Mary Jordan wrote a book about {"uri": "8232776407", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:43:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:43:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:41:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/melania-trump-watches-husbands-convention-033609475.html", "title": "Melania Trump watches husband's convention speech in rare appearance", "body": "Sarah Smith - North America editor, at the Republican convention in Milwaukee\n\nDonald Trump's elusive wife Melania has appeared in public for the first time since the former president narrowly missed an assassin's bullet.\n\nWearing Republican red she walked, alone, into the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee accompanied by classical music - a marked contrast from the country music anthems and rock ballads we've been hearing all week.\n\nGlossy and glamorous, she looked more like she was walking down a catwalk than into a political convention. She seemed as inscrutable and distant as ever.\n\nEver since her husband was first elected in 2016, Melania Trump has broken all the rules of normal American presidential politics.\n\nIn the White House during Trump's first term, she was a reclusive figure compared to other first ladies, focusing on a narrow set of interests. The US national archives descibes her as having been an \"ambassador for kindness\" and an advocate for children's issues.\n\nAnd since her husband left office, she has refused to be seen by her husband's side on many occasions when the public would expect her to be present.\n\nShe wasn't there when he had his mugshot taken in Atlanta. She wasn't there in New York when he became the first former president to be convicted of a crime. And she wasn't there when he officially won his party's presidential nomination, for the third time, on Monday.\n\n\"Melania does what Melania wants,\" said Mary Jordan, who wrote The Art of her Deal, a biography on the former first lady. \"She is fiercely independent and won't do something just because other people do it. She doesn't feel any obligation to do it.\"\n\nWe are now all accustomed to the fact that she doesn't turn up at many of Donald Trump's events, but on Monday, when he walked into the arena here in Milwaukee to a roaring welcome, greeted like a Messiah after his survival of the assassination attempt, her absence felt particularly obvious.\n\nIt was certainly noticed by the Republicans gathered here, but that didn't mean they weren't excited for her appearance, when it finally came.\n\nMelania is the most enigmatic first lady in modern history and we rarely hear what she thinks.\n\nAn exception was the lengthy statement she released after the shooting targeting her husband, which read as though she may have dictated it directly.\n\n\"A monster who recognized my husband as an inhuman political machine attempted to ring out Donald's passion - his laughter, ingenuity, love of music, and inspiration,\" she said.\n\n\"The core facets of my husband's life - his human side - were buried below the political machine. Donald, the generous and caring man who I have been with through the best of times and the worst of times.\"\n\nIt is traditional at party conventions for the candidate's spouse to give a speech and tell heavily-scripted anecdotes about family life.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, Usha Vance - the wife of Trump's newly-minted running mate JD Vance - did just that. She called her husband a \"meat and potatoes\" man, but - in an apparent sign of his devotion - said he now cooked her Indian vegetarian food.\n\nAnd while Donald Trump's oldest son Don Jr, middle son Eric, daughter-in-law Lara and granddaughter Kai have all spoken at this convention, Melania has declined the opportunity to speak. She very clearly does not do anything she does not want to do.\n\nWhen she did introduce her husband at the 2016 convention when he first ran for president - things went horribly wrong.\n\nShe was criticised for plagiarising the speech Michelle Obama gave in 2008 when she introduced her husband Barack at the Democratic convention. Melania's speechwriter later accepted the blame.\n\nFirst ladies are always heavily scrutinised for the image they project, the causes they adopt, and the clothes they wear.\n\nBut Melania Trump is the first who was previously a professional model. She looks fabulous in photographs and is well aware of the power of her image. By offering so few photo opportunities, she makes each one infinitely more powerful.\n\n\"She is very savvy and has cultivated the mystery woman mystique by going underground and then when she does come out, it's a much bigger deal,\" says Ms Jordan.\n\n\"She doesn't appear very often, but she does show up when Donald Trump really needs her.\"\n\nAfter Saturday's attempt on his life, Melania felt MIA. {"uri": "8232395074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "20:16:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T20:16:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T20:15:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/18/us/politics/melania-trump-2024-campaign-republicans.html", "title": "Ever Elusive, Melania Trump Expected to Appear at G.O.P. Convention", "body": "The former first lady skipped much of the Trump family reunion in Milwaukee this week.\n\nThe Republican National Convention has been chockablock with Trumps.\n\nLara Trump, the co-chair of the Republican Party and Donald J. Trump's daughter-in-law, delivered a keynote address. Her husband, Eric, has made the rounds on cable news. Another Trump son, Donald Trump Jr., spoke for 19 minutes on Wednesday night, long enough even to hand the mic to his teenage daughter, Kai.\n\nAnd yet, where is Melania?\n\nDonald Trump's wife has remained out of sight. She has not been in the V.I.P. box where Mr. Trump has presided over the prime-time show each night. She has not been on television. She is sparsely featured in the videos played for delegates between speakers and in the photos plastered on the arena's walls.\n\nMrs. Trump is set to appear on Thursday, as her husband delivers his acceptance speech on the convention's final night. But, in a break from tradition, she is not expected to speak. (Other Trumps are likely to make their first appearances, too: Ivanka, the former president's daughter who is keeping a distance from his current campaign, and Barron, 18, Mr. Trump's youngest son.)\n\nAt this celebration of all things Trump, nobody knows quite what to make of this.\n\nScott Walker, the former governor of Wisconsin, speculated on Wednesday from the floor of the convention hall that it is probably just \"too overwhelming\" for Mrs. Trump, given the assassination attempt on her husband on Saturday. \"I think it's going to be emotional even to be with him,\" Mr. Walker said, \"let alone speak.\"\n\nAsked about the former first lady on Tuesday, Matt Schlapp, a former White House aide, shrugged. \"I don't know whether she's coming or not,\" he said. \"Melania has always taken full measure of her ability to have private time for as long as possible. I know that she's completely behind this campaign.\"\n\nMrs. Trump has been disappearing from view for a while now. She did not show up at her husband's trial for falsifying business records to cover up hush payments to Stormy Daniels, a porn star who claimed to have had a tryst with Mr. Trump while his wife was home with a newborn. {"uri": "8233016839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "07:15:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T07:15:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T07:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/news/irish-news/melania-trump-appears-first-time-33278078", "title": "Melania struts into RNC appearing in public for first time since Trump shooting", "body": "Melania Trump stood by her husband as he delivered his speech on Thursday night, strutting into the final day of the 2024 Republican National Convention, looking glamorous and sporting a striking red dress as she made quite the entrance.\n\nThe ex-first lady had been notably absent for most of the RNC, despite her spouse being confirmed as the Republican presidential candidate earlier that week. Spouses of presidential hopefuls traditionally address the RNC crowd; Melania herself took the stage in both the 2016 and 2020 conventions, where her speeches bore striking resemblances to those of former first lady Michelle Obama.\n\nThis appearance follows shortly after Melania's public statement regarding the assassination attempt on Donald Trump last Saturday at a campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania. \"When I watched that violent bullet strike my husband, Donald, I realised my life, and Barron's life, were on the brink of devastating change,\" she said in her statement.\n\nREAD MORE: Donald Trump's assassination attempt was 'top of Putin's wishlist' as US hit by 'political chaos'\n\nThe final day of the conference has seen a wide variety of speakers, from the general manager of Trump's golf resorts to former pro wrestler Hulk Hogan, who shredded his shirt in front of attendees as he shared his passion for \"Trumpmania.\"\n\nFormer first lady Melania Trump was cheered loudly when mentioned by other speakers during the previous nights, but she finally entered the arena on the final night wearing a red jacket and pencil skirt suit and waving to the crowds.\n\nMelania has been conspicuously absent from the ex-president's campaign trail, reports the Mirror US.\n\nThe former First Lady appeared dressed all in red as she walked into the Milwaukee convention hall, shortly before her husband took to the stage. The speech marks his first public comments since a 20-year-old with a rifle tried to shoot him at a Pennsylvania rally on Saturday.\n\nShe will not be speaking at the convention. Her office was the one that declined an invitation for Barron Trump to appear as a Florida delegate after the state's Republican party chose him to join the delegation saying the couple's youngest son had \"prior commitments.\"\n\nHer presence helps the Republican party show unity, a theme that has emerged more prominently after the attempt on Trump's life. {"uri": "2024-07-427528501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:41:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:41:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:29:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://eu.palmbeachpost.com/story/news/2024/07/19/melania-trump-wedding-mar-lago-florida-ivanka/74376633007/", "title": "Donald and Melania Trump, Don Jr., Eric, Ivanka, Tiffany: Which weddings included Mar-a-Lago", "body": "Soon, Donald and Melania Trump will celebrate a milestone wedding anniversary. On Jan. 25, 2025, the former first couple will toast 20 years of marriage.\n\nTwenty years ago, Donald Trump and then-fianc\u00e9 Melania Knauss, her professional modeling name, were busy planning their lavish nuptials in Palm Beach, Florida - the wedding at Bethesda-By-the-Sea Episcopal Church, followed by a wedding reception in the new Donald J. Trump Ballroom at his private club.\n\nMuch has happened since the Trumps tied the knot; his third trip down the aisle and her first:\n\nAnd a lot has happened to the wedding venue Mar-a-Lago since 2005: Several Trump family members were married or hosted wedding receptions there. Ahead of the milestone wedding anniversary of Donald and Melania Trump, here's a look at who (and who didn't) include Trump's private club Mar-a-Lago in their wedding nuptials.\n\nWhat was Melania Trump's maiden name?\n\nMelania Trump was born Melanija Knavs April 26, 1970, in Novo Mesto, Slovenia, according to her bio on the White House Historical Association's website. As Melania Knauss, she began her modeling career at age 16 and moved to New York in 1996. Donald Trump met the model in 1998 at a New York fashion party, became engaged in 2004 and married in 2005.\n\nTwenty years ago, Melania Knauss was just a bride-to-be, squeezing in wedding dress fittings, finalizing celebrity invites and reception dinner at Mar-a-Lago. Melania Knauss became Mrs. Donald Trump on a Saturday evening in January 2005.\n\nPhotos looking back at the wedding of Donald and Melania Trump\n\nThe photo gallery below is a look back at wedding preparations for Donald and Melania Trump and what we know about their Jan. 25, 2005, wedding, from archived photos and coverage of the Palm Beach Post, the Palm Beach Daily News and USA TODAY Network-Florida.\n\nWhere did Donald Trump Jr. get married?\n\nOn Nov. 12, 2005, Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of Donald Trump and first wife Ivana Trump, married former model Vanessa Kay Trump, formerly Vanessa Kay Pergolizzi. Donald Trump introduced Donald Trump Jr. to Vanessa at a fashion show in 2003. The couple married at Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach in front of about 370 guests, reports show, with the service officiated by Donald Trump's sister, Judge Maryanne Trump Barry. Donald Trump Jr. and Vanessa Trump were 27 years old when they wed, weeks before they both turned 28 in December 2005.\n\nDonald Trump Jr.'s siblings were in the wedding party: Ivanka Trump was a bridesmaid, and Eric Trump was a groomsman.\n\nVanessa and Donald Trump Jr. had five children together - Kai Trump, Donald Trump III, Tristan Trump, Spencer Trump and Chloe Trump - before they eventually divorced, after 12 years of marriage, in 2018.\n\nDonald Trump Jr. is engaged to Kimberly Guilfoyle.\n\nWhere did Eric Trump and Lara Trump get married?\n\nOn Nov. 8, 2014, after a six-year relationship, Lara Yunaska married Eric Trump in a ceremony at Mar-a-Lago. Eric Trump, then 30 and son of Donald Trump and his first wife, Ivana Trump, married the TV producer in a ceremony that included 450 guests and was held on the lawn of the Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Florida, USA TODAY reports in a November 2014 story.\n\nWedding guests included Eric Trump's mom Ivana Trump, radio personality Elvis Duran and former \"Real Housewives of New York\" star Jill Zarin, according to People magazine.\n\nThe family of Eric Trump's sister, Ivanka Trump, had roles in the wedding: Ivanka Trump's daughter was a flower girl and Ivanka Trump's husband, Jared Kushner, officiated at the wedding, according to the Daily News. The Daily Mail reports that Lara Trump's dog, Charlie, was the ring bearer.\n\nTwo weeks before her wedding to Eric Trump, the bride, Lara Yunaska, broke both of her wrists in a horse riding accident. She chose to wear Vera Wang -- one gown for the ceremony and another for the reception.\n\nWhere did Ivanka Trump marry Jared Kushner?\n\nOn Oct. 25, 2009, Ivanka Trump, eldest daughter of Donald and Ivana Trump, married Jared Kushner, who previously owned the New York Observer. The 27-year-old bride and 28-year-old groom tied the knot at Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey, in front of about 500 guests.\n\nNews reports show the guest list included celebrities such as Russell Crowe, Regis Philbin, Natalie Portman, Barbara Walters, Rudy Giuliani, Andrew Cuomo, country singer Jamey Johnson, Emmy Rossum and then-boyfriend Adam Duritz of the band Counting Crows.\n\nIvanka Trump wore a Vera Wang gown reminiscent of Princess Grace Kelly's wedding dress. Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner are parents to three children, Arabella Rose Kushner, Joseph Frederick Kushner and Theodore James Kushner.\n\nWhere did Tiffany Trump get married?\n\nOn Nov. 12, 2022, Tiffany Trump and Michael Boulos were married at Donald Trump's private club Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida. More than 500 guests attended the wedding of the former president's youngest daughter, then 29, to the 25-year-old Lebanese-American billionaire. Tiffany Trump is the younger daughter of the former president and his second wife Marla Maples.\n\nThe couple, who got engaged after two years of dating, met in 2018, when Boulos was studying project management at City University of London and Tiffany Trump was a law student at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. Both were vacationing in Santorini and met in Mykonos at Lindsay Lohan's Beach Club, according to People magazine.\n\nTiffany Trump announced her engagement to Boulos on her father's last day in office; her fiance proposed in the White House Rose Garden. In an homage to her husband's Lebanese heritage, the bride chose Lebanese designer Elie Saab to design her dress, according to the Palm Beach Daily News.\n\nThree days before the wedding, Florida was in the path of Hurricane Nicole. The wedding occurred without issue from the storm.\n\nThey do! {"uri": "8232802066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "04:10:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T04:10:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T04:09:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/3ad6bb32-0a35-4c77-a6b6-1e4c47633076", "title": "Melania Trump doesn't really care, do u?", "body": "Melania Trump has some chutzpah. While Jill Biden, America's current First Lady, goes around fiercely defending her doddery husband and congratulating him on managing to answer \"every question\" as if he were a three-year-old child, the previous -- and likely, for her sins, returning -- Flotus doesn't even show up to stand by her husband's side two days after a bullet intended to assassinate him blew off part of his ear.\n\nDonald Trump seemed unusually subdued and emotional on Monday night when he made his first public appearance since the shooting at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee. His eldest son, Donald Trump Jr, appeared to have tears in his eyes as the former president walked out alone into the auditorium to the rousing sound of God Bless the USA, a large white bandage covering most of his right ear. Eric was there to support his father too, while youngest daughter Tiffany turned up to do her usual vacant smiling.\n\nBut Melania, in trademark DGAF style, was nowhere to be seen. On Tuesday evening, it was Trump's daughter-in-law Lara who talked of the horror of watching \"someone try to kill a person you love\", in the RNC slot usually reserved for the wife of the presidential nominee.\n\nThe only words Melania has so far uttered on the subject of the violent attempt on her husband's life have been via a written statement shared on social media -- one that had a distinct whiff of the ChatGPT (not to mention the Google Translate) about it.\n\n\"A monster who recognised my husband as an inhuman political machine attempted to ring out Donald's passion -- his laughter, ingenuity, love of music, and inspiration,\" the statement read. \"Our personal, structural and life commitment -- until death -- is at serious risk.\"\n\nWell, the sentiment is there, and I liked it, personally. You might have supposed Melania would have a member of staff look over the statement before making it public. But to suppose, when it comes to Melania Trump, is to make a grave error. It takes a certain kind of woman to keep a man like Donald Trump on his toes, after all. And she has done so for more than 20 years, by virtue of a mystique that swings wildly between the bizarre and the brazen.\n\nMelania clings to the faux pas as if it were her favourite Herm\u00e8s bag. Who could forget her 2016 speech at the RNC, which cribbed large chunks of Michelle Obama's 2008 address to the Democratic convention (her speechwriter later took responsibility for this)? Or the time, later that year, that she turned up to a presidential debate wearing a bright pink pussy-bow blouse just two days after audio had been released of her husband boasting of how he likes to \"grab 'em by the pussy\"?\n\nThe vestiary reference was, reportedly, \"not intentional\". Neither, presumably, was the pattern of the stitching on the coat she wore for a tribute to 9/11 in 2019, which oddly resembled a plane crashing into one of the Twin Towers (a spokeswoman called the suggestion \"ridiculous\").\n\nBut the time she set off for the detention centre for migrant children wearing a $39 Zara jacket emblazoned with the words \"I REALLY DON'T CARE DO U?\" -- that was deliberate. She said in an interview in 2018 that the message was intended not for the migrant children, but for \"the people and for the leftwing media who are criticising me. And I want to show them that I don't care.\"\n\nThe leftwing media are not the only ones in Melania's firing line; virtually every anecdote Trump shares about his wife seems to be some account of her negging him. When he was complaining that the lighting was too bright at a rally last year, Trump told the crowd: \"When you go home to watch it with our great First Lady, how did I look? She said: you didn't look good!\" In a different speech, Trump admitted that \"she doesn't like when I dance a little bit to the music.\"\n\nMelania has shown up to none of Trump's recent court appearances, and virtually none of his campaign events. I've lost track of the number of times I've seen her turn her head when her husband tries to kiss her, or that her facial expression has given away her lack of interest in one of the rare appearances she has deigned to make. The only person who can drop a smile more quickly is Kanye West.\n\nGiven the comments he has made about women and the number of sexual assault allegations that have been made about him -- not to mention his unfaithfulness -- you might have supposed Trump would choose as his wife a submissive type. But again, you would be wrong. Trump, clearly, is someone to whom the \"treat 'em mean, keep 'em keen\" rule applies.\n\nWhen I was lunching on the patio at Mar-a-Lago in February, as one does, Melania walked by to get to the spa -- the only route from her living quarters -- in a full face of make-up, her hair freshly blow-dried. What a chore, I thought, to constantly have to be so aware of your appearance. But I did not pity her. \"People think and talk about me like: Oh, Melania, oh poor Melania. Don't feel sorry for me,\" she once said -- rather threateningly, I fancied. {"uri": "8232778782", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "03:52:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T03:52:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T03:44:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/melania-trump-watches-husbands-convention-033609475.html", "title": "Melania Trump watches husband's convention speech in rare appearance", "body": "Wearing Republican red she walked, alone, into the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee accompanied by classical music - a marked contrast from the country music anthems and rock ballads we've been hearing all week.\n\nGlossy and glamorous, she looked more like she was walking down a catwalk than into a political convention. She seemed as inscrutable and distant as ever.\n\nEver since her husband was first elected in 2016, Melania Trump has broken all the rules of normal American presidential politics.\n\nIn the White House during Trump's first term, she was a reclusive figure compared to other first ladies, focusing on a narrow set of interests. The US national archives descibes her as having been an \"ambassador for kindness\" and an advocate for children's issues.\n\nAnd since her husband left office, she has refused to be seen by her husband's side on many occasions when the public would expect her to be present.\n\nShe wasn't there when he had his mugshot taken in Atlanta. She wasn't there in New York when he became the first former president to be convicted of a crime. And she wasn't there when he officially won his party's presidential nomination, for the third time, on Monday.\n\n\"Melania does what Melania wants,\" said Mary Jordan, who wrote The Art of her Deal, a biography on the former first lady. \"She is fiercely independent and won't do something just because other people do it. She doesn't feel any obligation to do it.\"\n\nWe are now all accustomed to the fact that she doesn't turn up at many of Donald Trump's events, but on Monday, when he walked into the arena here in Milwaukee to a roaring welcome, greeted like a Messiah after his survival of the assassination attempt, her absence felt particularly obvious.\n\nIt was certainly noticed by the Republicans gathered here, but that didn't mean they weren't excited for her appearance, when it finally came.\n\nMelania is the most enigmatic first lady in modern history and we rarely hear what she thinks.\n\nAn exception was the lengthy statement she released after the shooting targeting her husband, which read as though she may have dictated it directly.\n\n\"A monster who recognized my husband as an inhuman political machine attempted to ring out Donald's passion - his laughter, ingenuity, love of music, and inspiration,\" she said.\n\n\"The core facets of my husband's life - his human side - were buried below the political machine. Donald, the generous and caring man who I have been with through the best of times and the worst of times.\"\n\nIt is traditional at party conventions for the candidate's spouse to give a speech and tell heavily-scripted anecdotes about family life.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, Usha Vance - the wife of Trump's newly-minted running mate JD Vance - did just that. She called her husband a \"meat and potatoes\" man, but - in an apparent sign of his devotion - said he now cooked her Indian vegetarian food.\n\nAnd while Donald Trump's oldest son Don Jr, middle son Eric, daughter-in-law Lara and granddaughter Kai have all spoken at this convention, Melania has declined the opportunity to speak. She very clearly does not do anything she does not want to do.\n\nWhen she did introduce her husband at the 2016 convention when he first ran for president - things went horribly wrong.\n\nShe was criticised for plagiarising the speech Michelle Obama gave in 2008 when she introduced her husband Barack at the Democratic convention. Melania's speechwriter later accepted the blame.\n\nFirst ladies are always heavily scrutinised for the image they project, the causes they adopt, and the clothes they wear.\n\nBut Melania Trump is the first who was previously a professional model. She looks fabulous in photographs and is well aware of the power of her image. By offering so few photo opportunities, she makes each one infinitely more powerful.\n\n\"She is very savvy and has cultivated the mystery woman mystique by going underground and then when she does come out, it's a much bigger deal,\" says Ms Jordan.\n\n\"She doesn't appear very often, but she does show up when Donald Trump really needs her.\"\n\nAfter Saturday's attempt on his life, Melania felt MIA. {"uri": "8232337573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:21:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:21:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:20:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.msnbc.com/opinion/msnbc-opinion/melania-trump-rnc-will-not-speak-rcna161908", "title": "Opinion | Melania Trump is making history tonight", "body": "Melania Trump is planning to attend the Republican National Convention but does not plan to speak. Her silence highlights how she has significantly reshaped the role of first lady.\n\nA year ago this spring, when the 2024 presidential campaign was just kicking off, it seemed evident that Melania Trump, wife of former President Donald Trump, had decided to give it a miss. Little has changed since then. Her continued detachment from campaign events and rallies, her absence in all the primaries save Florida's (where she voted), her skipping her husband's lengthy hush money trial and his June 28 debate against President Joe Biden come alongside the strong speculation that she won't live full-time in the White House again should Trump be re-elected.\n\nAll of it taken together seems only to confirm that her distance from Trump's political life will continue no matter what happens Nov. 5. Melania Trump has, it is true, held two campaign fundraisers for the Log Cabin Republicans at her homes; but by contrast, first lady Jill Biden has held frequent fundraising tours with multiple destinations.\n\nJill Biden, described as \"defender-in-chief\" of her husband's campaign by the Economist, and described by The New York Times as \"comforter-in-chief\" to some jittery Democrats, has visited red states and blue ones, often alone, and been an actively political surrogate for her husband. Melania Trump's limited appearances could not be in starker contrast.\n\nThough she has been harder to find, Melania Trump is planning to attend the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee. However, unlike she did in 2016 and 2020, this time she does not plan to speak. Her silence will end an unbroken tradition that goes back to Barbara Bush in 1992 of first ladies and candidates' spouses giving significant addresses at conventions.\n\nAs long as she is visible at the convention, even if she's silent, Melania Trump will win plaudits from Trump fans, many of whom only want more of her. Still, her silence and her rare appearances are further evidence, as Katie Rogers noted recently, that Melania Trump has significantly reshaped the role of first lady: \"She broke open the role and actually showed us [that] you don't have to do anything with it if you don't want to.\"\n\nFor more than a century, whether they desired it or not, first ladies have been highly visible campaigners. As many American women got to vote for the first time in 1920, for example, Florence Harding eagerly stood on her front porch, in what was called the Front Porch Campaign, hosting tens of thousands of visitors alongside her husband, President Warren G. Harding. Similarly, Eleanor Roosevelt called for Franklin D. Roosevelt's unprecedented third term during her \"no ordinary time\" speech at the Democratic convention in 1940, a step that, as First Ladies Association for Research and Education President Nancy Kegan Smith notes, \"was credited with helping FDR to unify the convention.\"\n\nTwo decades later, Lady Bird Johnson was the first to take to the hustings on her own, with the whistle-stop tour in 1964 -- a bold venture into a hostile South that helped bring about LBJ's victory. Pat Nixon was the next to appear at a convention, in 1972, thrilled to offer remarks about her husband, Richard Nixon, following an eight-minute standing ovation. Then in 1992, Barbara Bush, already known for a significant speech at Wellesley College, had the opportunity to speak \"about the centrality of family ... in a model of conciliatory rhetoric,\" as scholar Myra Gutin explains.\n\nSince then, first ladies' speeches at conventions have often focused on family matters; Hillary Clinton spoke of children and family in 1996, as did Michelle Obama in 2008: \"I come here as a wife; I come here as a mom.\" In 2012, Michelle Obama further highlighted hers and President Barack Obama's humble family histories. In 2020, during the coronavirus pandemic, Jill Biden offered a speech \"as a mother and a grandmother\" from a classroom at a high school where she once taught. Both Melania Trump's speeches in 2016 and 2020 were similarly focused on family, addressing mothers like herself -- and women as a whole.\n\nThis theme of family was also echoed by Melania Trump this past weekend in the wake of the assassination attempt on her husband. In an effort to reach across the aisle, she pointed out that \"every single politician is a man or a woman with a loving family.\" Her statement was heartfelt and empathic, calling for Americans to see each other as \"human beings.\" Considering her absence during so much of the campaign so far, her outspokenness at this moment was notable -- and will likely carry significant political weight. Her comments, of course, stand in stark contrast to the way her husband told supporters to \"fight like hell\" right before the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021.\n\nMelania Trump's words were important in humanizing her husband, and they suggest that GOP strategist Alex Conant is overlooking something significant when he claims that \"people vote for the presidential candidate, not their spouse or their vice president.\" This is because for more than a century now, whether they are particularly interested in politicking or not, first ladies have served their spouses' campaigns immeasurably, by humanizing and broadening their appeal. With her statement, Melania Trump did just that after the assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania. And Jill Biden's call to her in the wake of the attack underlined the sisterhood of first ladies, all of whom know that what happened Saturday is what each of them dreads the most.", "source": {"uri": "msnbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MSNBC.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Lady_of_the_United_States", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "First Lady of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melania_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Melania Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jill_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jill Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Republican National Convention"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_2016_presidential_campaign", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log_Cabin_Republicans", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Log Cabin Republicans"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Bush", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Barbara Bush"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_states_and_blue_states", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Red states and blue states"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Franklin D. {"uri": "8232794919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "04:04:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T04:04:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T04:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/watch-what-donald-trump-said-about-wife-melania-trump-at-rnc/articleshow/111850908.cms", "title": "Watch: What Donald Trump said about wife Melania Trump at RNC - Times of India", "body": "Donald Trump's wife Melania Trump on Thursday made a rare appearance at the Republican National Convention to show her support for her husband's 2024 presidential campaign.\n\nAs she entered the arena, she was greeted with warm applause and waved to the crowd before taking her seat. Unlike the Republican conventions in 2016 and 2020, she was not scheduled to deliver a speech.\n\nIvanka Trump, Donald Trump's daughter, and her husband, Jared Kushner, who have also been absent from the campaign trail, joined the former first lady in the family box, in contrast to their involvement in previous campaigns.\n\nDuring his speech, former President Donald Trump took a moment to express his appreciation for his wife, stating, \"I am deeply honoured to be joined by my amazing wife Melania.\"\n\nHe also acknowledged Melania's letter, which was released in the wake of the assassination attack and called for national unity. Trump commended her efforts, saying, \"Melania thank you very much you also did something really beautiful a letter to America for national Unity and it really took the Republican party by surprise, it was beautiful.\"\n\nTrump emphasised the letter's significance, stating, \"The letter captivated so many,\" highlighting its profound effect on the audience.\n\nMelania Trump's statement was released in a letter following an assassination attempt on former US President Donald Trump.\n\nThe former president was the target of an apparent assassination attempt during a rally in Pennsylvania, just days before he was set to accept the Republican nomination for the third time.
